Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Support for Political Networks Conference and Training Workshops

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

As a field of study, network methods are relatively new to the discipline of political science; however, they are critical to questions of politics. At its core, politics involves human interaction. For too long politics has been studied as a process focused on individuals, where scholars have understood that individuals' incentives and choices are shaped by the rules and institutions around them. This tradition comes from economics, largely. However, as a social science, it is imperative for scholars to ask and answer puzzles about politics that recognize the relational nature of politics. Political actions cannot be understood in the absence of a recognition that political actors' choices are dependent on others in their network. This is true about voters, legislators, dictators, countries, and all types of political actors. This award provides supplemental support for PhD students and junior faculty to travel to attend the Political Networks Conference and Training Workshops. The resources provided by this grant are dedicated to support graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and under-funded assistant professors, expand diversity efforts, extend mentoring and networking efforts, and encourage the development and dissemination of new methods and theories appropriate for the specific needs of subfields brought together by an interest in studying political networks. The training workshops leverage participants' strengths in training and mentoring to advance the field of political networks and foster interdisciplinary ties in this important methodological area.


Technical Summary

This is a particularly promising period for the development of network studies in politics. Extensive big data sets, expanded computational capabilities, and newly-developed analytic techniques have reduced many of the past obstacles to the serious study of political networks. Hence the study of political networks is at an important juncture, supported by newly established interdisciplinary organizations, an organized section, and training efforts that are currently underway. As a consequence, network studies have gained supporters and practitioners in virtually every area of political study; political institutions, comparative politics, political behavior, international relations, public policy, parties and elections, public opinion, interest groups, social movements, and political communication. The resources provided by this grant are dedicated to support graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and under-funded assistant professors, expand diversity efforts, extend mentoring and networking efforts, and encourage the development and dissemination of new methods and theories appropriate for the specific needs of subfields brought together by an interest in studying political networks. The training workshops leverage participants' strengths in training and mentoring to advance the field of political networks and foster interdisciplinary ties in this important methodological area. The training and conference is interdisciplinary by design, and it is exciting to see deep and extensive engagement across disciplines. The grant is aimed specifically to achieve training and learning for participants. In addition, the goal is that participants then take what they learn and move it into their graduate and undergraduate teaching and contribute to quantitative social science programs at their home institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the Political Networks conference and workshops has been remarkable. The grant helped to support 4 annual meetings, in 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019. Over the course of these events, 28 workshop sessions were presented by leading scholars, often inventors and developers themselves, to crowded rooms of eager learners. The level of instruction that participants received was high, as instructors provided tutorials in state-of-the-art software and technologies for network analysis, as well as high-level theory, research design, and guidance on developing rigorous research in political science using network theory or methods. The intellectual merit of the events was further enhanced by 3 plenary session keynote addresses offered by leading scholars adjacent to political science, from communications, sociology, and network science.

 

In addition, over the course of these four events 250 academic papers were presented on panels where scholars shared research findings, sought instant peer-review feedback on works in progress, and answered questions from curious audience members. PolNet panel, poster, and plenary sessions are nearly always well-attended by registrants. The academic community generated by these events is strong, enthusiastic, and welcoming of newcomers. Over the course of these events 162 academic posters were presented at poster sessions were junior faculty and graduates students, particularly, have earned excellent feedback from the community.

 

Altogether, the four events had 559 non-unique registrants. Of these, 162 received funding support through this NSF grant to support their travel and participation. In other words, more than a quarter of PolNet participants over the past four years have been able to benefit from the intellectual community of the event directly because of the NSF support.

 

The broader impacts of having provided support for 162 PolNet Fellows over four years are significant. Since the vast majority of participants have been graduate students and junior faculty, many of these participants have taken their sills back to their home institutions to use in their own work and share with others. Any of the participants who learn network theory and methods, and later teach a methods oriented course will nearly always draw on their PolNet lessons to incorporate them into syllabi, curricula, and papers. In this way, the PolNet workshops have a multiplier effect. This is particularly important for scholars from underrepresented groups, who may have less general access to methods topics outside of a PhD program?s core curriculum.

 

Another way to observe the broader impacts of PolNet is to observe the rise in social science journals publishing articles with ?networks? in their title. The number of articles published in top political science journals that have ?networks? in their title, has double since 2008, according to Web of Science. Of course, most of this upward trend is due to increasing disciplinary interest in network science and relational statistics and is not directly attributable to a PolNet effect. The impact of PolNet is an endogenous feature of a relational phenomenon itself, ironically. It is difficult to untangle the impact of PolNet on scientific advancement as being distinct from the counterfactual case in which disciplinary interest in networks advanced in the absence of PolNet. However, it seems notable that since 2018, a majority of the articles published in top political science journals with ?networks? in their title have been authored or co-authored by scholars who have participated in PolNet.

 

Most importantly, PolNet provides training on an important scholarly topic that is not regularly taught in graduate programs around the country. While more and more programs are starting to include network methods as part of their training, it is still not the norm. PolNet provides a welcoming, accessible venue for receiving that training from some of the best instructors possible. In the absence of PolNet, fewer scholars will have access to these important methods that are helping to shed insight on some of the most important questions of our time. Network methods have contributed to our fundamental understanding about why people vote, why countries go to war, and how legislation is advanced. It is vitally important that network methods remain available to as wide of a population of scholars as possible.
